sections.title: Specifications
content: This is the Hyperloop pod that we are building. The GOOSE I is our half-scale, functional prototype vehicle pod. Fabrication for the pod is already underway and the funding from our Kickstarter will be used to complete its construction. This pod is entered in the SpaceX Hyperloop Pod Competition to perform full systems tests on SpaceX’s one mile long test track at high-speeds and in a vacuum.
The prototype is about 0.8m  (32") wide, 2.5m (8') long, 0.9m (36") tall, around 250 kg in weight, and will travel at 550km/h (150m/s).

sections.title: Pod Shell
content: The shell is designed to be as lightweight as possible while withstanding all of the forces it will be subjected to in the one-mile long test drive. This is made possible by introducing a geodetic diagrid frame which is designed to accept the applied forces better than a standard rectilinear frame. Although this style of framing has traditionally been considered more difficult to manufacture, this is quickly overcome with modern technology by precision modelling of the entire assembly in 3D, and the use of rapid fabrication technology including laser cutting and 3D printing.

sections.title: Levitation System
content: Air levitation through the form of four air casters is supplied via two on-board air tanks. The air casters create a thin sheet of air similar to an air hockey table upon which our pod floats. Air levitation is significantly less expensive and produces less drag than magnetic levitation. Although air caster technology has been in use for decades and is well understood, our levitation system is the first of its kind.

sections.title: Braking
content: Our hybrid braking system is mechanically fail-safe and functions even if all other systems fail. A combination of eddy current braking and friction braking is used. This allows for greater control over heat generation, higher performance, lower maintenance, and safety through redundancy.

sections.title: Eddy Current Braking
content: Our state-of-the-art contactless eddy current braking system uses 84 neodymium magnets arranged in a Halbach array. This arrangement doubles the magnetic strength on one side and cancels it out on the other. Braking force is achieved by exploiting the same drag produced in magnetic levitation - or when a permanent magnet is dropped down a copper tube. As the permanent magnets approach the I-beam while the pod is in motion, tiny circular electrical currents called eddy currents are induced within the beam which smoothly slows the pod down in a highly controlled fashion.

sections.title: Friction Braking
content: Our friction braking system is simple yet effective. Special brake linings made of resin-bonded synthetic rubber with steel fibres allow for effective energy transformation and heat dissipation, sparing damage to the I-beam.

sections.title: Lateral Control
content: The lateral control system uses two sets of spring-loaded caster wheels to maintain the lateral stability of the Goose I, with respect to the I-beam of the Hypertube. The system combines reliability, efficiency, safety, and comfort by using high speed, high performance, and dampened wheels.

sections.title: Drive Train
content: The Low-speed Drive system allows for taxiing before the test, in order to position for launch, and after the test so that the pod can exit the Hypertube. This system uses an air cylinder to retract the drive wheel into the pod during high speed travel. A set of four idler wheels keep the air casters from contacting the ground when levitation stops.

sections.title: Electrical and Embedded Systems
content: Electrical

The Electrical system is responsible for power distribution. Onboard power is delivered by a rechargeable 48V battery pack surrounded by a phase changing, fire-retardant matrix and enclosed in a sturdy PVC shell enclosure to keep it cool and secure.
EMBEDDED

The nervous system of our pod - using a multitude of sensors and actuators, the embedded system is responsible for the control of all other subsystems, position detection within the Hypertube, and communications between the pod and a remote control dashboard. This dashboard acts as a control center and a feed displaying information on the status of the pod.

sections.title: Specifications
content: The GOOSE II is our half-scale, functional prototype vehicle pod. Fabrication has been completed for this pod and we are testing it's capabilities currently. This pod is entered in the SpaceX Hyperloop Pod Competition to perform full systems tests on SpaceX’s one mile long test track at high-speeds and in a vacuum.
The prototype is about 0.5m  (20") wide, 2.5m (8') long, 0.8m (32") tall, around 150 kg in weight, and is designed to travel at speeds above 550km/h (150m/s).

sections.title: Levitation
content: A lightweight pneumatic levitation system that allows the pod to float over a thin cushion of compressed air – creating almost zero drag. Air is supplied by two high pressure carbon fiber tanks and sent to four air casters positioned underneath our levitation and suspension module. This module also deals with unevenness of the track and dampens vibrations produced while travelling at high speeds using shock absorbers.

sections.title: Eddy Current Brakes
content: Eddy current brakes, as its name suggests, is our contact-less braking system that utilizes the eddy current phenomena to smoothly slow down of the pod from high speeds. An array of powerful magnets are used to provide the braking effect.

sections.title: Magnetic Wheels
content: Inside each magnetic wheel is a ring of magnets arranged in a particular combination such that by spinning, each pair of magnetic wheels generate forces to keep the pod centered on the test track as well as propell the pod forward. High speed brushless DC motors allow us to have effective control over the pod even at high speeds.

sections.title: Shell
content: Incorporating beautiful and modern design while being operable at up to trans-sonic velocities. Its fiberglass composition means it can be lightweight yet strong.

sections.title: Specifications
content: Our pod design process for Competition III began with the goal of building the fastest pod. Based purely on specific power and energy of lithium ion batteries (and perhaps supercapacitors), it is theoretically possible to achieve speeds above Mach 1 within the 1-mile Hyperloop test track. This pod is designed to achieve 100m/s, and we are gradually working towards higher and higher speeds for future competitions.
The prototype is about 0.5m (20") wide, 2.7m (8.9') long, 0.8m (31.5") tall, around 150 kg in weight, and can theoretically reach speeds at or above Mach 1 (1235km/h, or 343m/s).

sections.title: Shell
content: Constructed out of fibreglass with a foam core for rigidity, the shell combines the efforts of all our subteam components into one cohesive whole. Separating the outer shell from the rest of the pod are rubber bushings to mitigate the effect of vibrations.

sections.title: Propulsion
content: The most challenging design yet, our propulsion system relies on a friction drive design to propel the pod forward. Using two rotating elements and a belt drive system, power is transferred from the motor to propel the pod along a surface safely and reliably. The friction drive design serves as a precursor to our Linear Induction Motor (LIM) design in later Goose pods.

sections.title: Brakes
content: With the constraint of 1.3 km of test track to work with comes the need to dissipate kinetic energy quickly. Our Eddy Current (EC) brakes work by inducing an eddy current in the web of the aluminum rail, creating opposing magnetic fields that work to brake the pod. They are also designed to counteract the stress produced by these potentially large forces.

sections.title: Lateral Wheels
content: Connecting the pod to the rails by the sides, these lateral wheels allow for a passive and lightweight lateral control system capable of supplying sufficient lateral forces to maintain stability.

sections.title: Frame
content: Similar to Goose II, we chose to use the ladder frame design with 2 L-beams connected by 4 I-beams. Improvements in the new frame design include a longer frame for the friction drive propulsion system and Eddy Current brakes, and a narrower frame to simplify component mounting and reduce torsional forces.

sections.title: Electrical
content: The nervous system of our pod, the electrical system connects the 24V and 567V powercells to the primitive sensors and motors installed throughout the pod. Arduino boards and Raspberry Pi's act as central hubs that interpret sensory data and control the flow of energy into each primitive module.

sections.title: Embedded
content: The embedded system serves as a bridge between the electrical system and the control system, and consists of three main components:
1. The Main Embedded Board (MEB) acts as the central hub for the Master Machines (i.e. 3 Raspberry Pi's),
• The Hub Processing Boards (HPB) act as a data centralization point and interfaces with the MEB to deliver the data; an Arduino Mega is used as the implementation for the HPB, and
• The Sensor and Control Hubs serve as efficient cable management and provide tools for low-level debugging. Three sensors are installed in the front, centre and rear of the pod.

sections.title: Control Systems
content: Based on the Master-Slave design model for maximum redundancy and safety, the design is based on 3 components:
1. Embedded-systems is responsible for all of the pod's internal interactions with the sensors and various health checks.
• Communication-systems is responsible for pod control and for transportation of information to the control-panel.
• Front-end displays all vital readings from the pod and provides a control interface while the pod is in the tube.

sections.title: Specifications
content: For GOOSE IV, we chose to dip our feet into the world of Linear Induction Motors by incorporating them into a conservative, safety-focused and low-cost subsystem design. GOOSE IV will become a stepping stone to GOOSE V, where we will be incorporating a fully contactless system alongside the LIM.
The prototype is about 0.4m (15.75") wide, 2.0m (6.56') long, 0.4m (15.75") tall, around 81.7 kg in weight, and is designed to reach a safe and slightly faster speed of 44m/s.

sections.title: Linear Induction Motor
content: A linear induction motor produces thrust through a linear force rather than through torque. This allows it to function on an unpowered conductive track, thereby saving costs in maintenance and per-unit track costs. Despite the disadvantage of end effects (or "turbulence") leading to lower speeds, the LIM offers contactless propulsion on a simpler track such as an aluminum one. Furthermore, the LIM allows for a centralized design that reduces the weight of the entire pod, and there are a variety of opportunities to scale up the LIM design and promises of better levitation technologies to use with the LIM.

sections.title: Low Speed Drive
content: Similar to the landing gear of an airplane, the low speed drive system serves as a fail-safe propulsion mechanism and a way to taxi the pod. Designed to operate at a speed of 3 m/s, the system consists of an electric hub motor that can be raised to reduce frictional force at higher speeds and lowered to safely drive the pod to the end of the track.

sections.title: Braking
content: Consisting of a 4-bar parallelogram linkage, these push the braking pads against the vertical section of the I-beam rail through a pneumatic actuator (air compression). This results in an effective and scalable braking system that can easily bring the pod to a safe stop from a high speed.

sections.title: Pneumatic Systems
content: Used by the Low Speed Drive and Braking systems, the pneumatic system applies the brakes for deceleration and also controls the Low Speed Drive for taxiing and as a fail-safe, with both systems being independent of each other.

sections.title: Frame
content: As the main structural component of the GOOSE IV pod, the frame supports all other subsytems in a fixed position and transfers the overall propulsion force to the entire pod. Weighing only 9 kg, the frame is designed to withstand all acceleration, braking, vibration and structural loads during the run.

sections.title: Shell
content: Designed with the focus on aesthetics, mass and aerodynamics, and inspired by the F-117 bomber, our smoked polycarbonate shell covers the entire pod while still allowing for its individual components to be shown and easily tweaked. Our GOOSE IV shell was also designed to stand out, with ample space to display our logo as well as promotional material.

sections.title: Guidance
content: Guiding the pod along the track, the guidance system provides lateral stability (so the pod doesn't tilt to one side) and controls vertical suspension. This system is split into the front and back of the pod, with the front holding the pod up and absorbing shocks from the track, and the back preventing the pod from derailing.

sections.title: Power
content: The power system comprises of 2 parts: High Voltage system (HV), and Low Voltage system (LV). The HV system powers the linear induction motor, while the LV system powers all other components on the pod. An enclosure is used to insulate the batteries used in the 2 systems, and a Battery Management system ensures that consistent and stable power is provided to the pod.

sections.title: Motor Control and Inverter
content: The primary way of controlling the operating speed of the Linear Induction Motor (LIM) is to use an inverter to adjust the AC output frequency to the LIM using the DC battery power supply. The controller is used to ensure a stable power output from the non-constant three-phase AC loead from the LIM, while also accounting for the end effects (or "turbulence") produced by the LIM.

sections.title: Software and Embedded
content: Designed with modularity and minimalism as a focus, the Software and Embedded team incorporates redundant and inexpensive devices that work together to control the pod. Multiple Raspberry Pis are used to aggregate data, communicate with the Arduinos through the CAN bus system and perform other complex tasks.

sections.title: Specifications
content: GOOSE V is the result of refinining and optimizing GOOSE IV. We decided to expand upon the feasibility of Linear Induction Motors by incorporating it alongside a conservative, scalable and cost-effective subsystem design approach. More specifically, our team has gained tremendous insights from testing a small-scale LIM prototype, a high speed flywheel braking rig and a physial battery failure scenario.
The prototype is about 0.533m (21.68") wide, 2.296m (7.5') long, 0.356m (14.76") tall, around 82 kg in weight, and is designed to reach a safe and faster speed of 44m/s.

sections.title: Linear Induction Motor
content: Like a Rotary Induction Motor but cut up on its centre axis and with the stator and rotor unrolled flat, a linear induction motor produces thrust through a linear force rather than through torque. This allows it to function on an unpowered conductive track, thereby saving costs in maintenance and per-unit track costs. Despite the disadvantage of end effects (or "turbulence") leading to lower speeds, the LIM offers contactless propulsion on a simpler track such as an aluminum one. Furthermore, the LIM allows for a centralized design that reduces the weight of the entire pod, and there are a variety of opportunities to scale up the LIM design and promises of better levitation technologies to use with the LIM. We use the DLIM (or Double-sided LIM) design, which involves 2 LIMs on either side of the I-beam track, to allow for a stronger magnetic field to be maintained.

sections.title: Frame
content: The main structural component of the pod, the frame houses all of the pod's mechanical and electrical subsytems. Made from 6061-T6 square aluminum tubing, the frame is welded in a truss structure and weighs 10 kg. The material and construction of the frame is designed to withstand all acceleration, braking, vibration and structural loads during the run.

sections.title: Guidance
content: The guidance system maintains lateral and horizontal stability. It accounts for any variations or imperfections in the track that may induce vibrations and bump impulses to the vehicle, and ensures the pod stays on track without damage. The guidance system also ensures that the pod maintains consistent contact with the track, as the LIM and sensors are affected by even the smallest of deviations.

The system comprises of 2 parts. The top/bottom components constrain the pod's vertical movements with wheels above the top and underside surfaces of the track, with 4 dampers mounted to the chassis for support and articulation over bumps. The lateral components exist to maintain a minimum gap between the 2 LIMs on either side of the pod to ensure continuous and proper propulsion force, thus keeping the pod laterally and rotationally centred on the track.

sections.title: Braking
content: The brakes are designed to slow the pod to a stop, whether the pod has reached its top speed, experienced a failure or to hold the pod stationary on the rail when powered off.

For Competition V, we used industry-leading Hyperloop-spec brakes produced by W.C. Branham in the USA. The brakes use coiled springs to apply the friction pads to the rail, and they are bolted to the frame with a support plate to ensure a robust mechanical system. The brakes are placed at the front and rear of the pod to maximize stopping force.

sections.title: Shell
content: The shell provides an external layer to the pod that decreases turbulence and stops foreign debris from entering the inner components. The shell design balances minimal manufacturing complexity and cost with aesthetical aspects for branding and promotional material.

sections.title: Motor Controller
content: The motor controller ultimately controls the Linear Induction Motors, and is split into 2 main portions: the power board, and the control board. The power board produces the 3-phase AC needed to power the LIM. This is achieved through the use of a IGBT 3-phase inverter. The control board acts as a medium between the power board and the microcontroller. Multiple systems are also used as sensors and protectors of the boards.

sections.title: Battery and Battery Management
content: The battery management system (BMS) is used to monitor and balance the cell array used to power the Linear Induction Motors and low voltage systems. The lithium ion cells experience multiple charge and discharge cycles, thus they will degrade if improperly managed without the BMS. The BMS also utilizes passive cell balancing to ensure that all batteries in the stack are evenly charged, thereby prolonging cell life and maintaining healthy charge levels.

sections.title: Embedded Sensors
content: The pod consists of an array of 32 sensors, with 11 unique models. A few examples of models would be the Piezo, which measures vibrations both at the wheel and frame level, and the Phototransitor that reads the RPM of the pod's wheels for calculating speed.

sections.title: Physical System Architecture: Communications
content: There are 2 major components comprising the communications system:

• The Networking and TCP component utilizes a Desktop Raspberry Pi. It facilitates relaying sensor data from the sensors to the desktop dashboard to be displayed, and to send commands from the remote desktop dashboard back to the pod.
• The CAN Bus connects a Raspberry Pi with Arduinos/Sensors. It serves as a cost-effective way of transmitting data between the devices with minimal interference from other subsystems in the pod.

sections.title: User Interface: Dashboard
content: Developed using QT Designer, QML and C++, the desktop system's dashboard displays sensor data about the pod's performance and provides a platform to control the pod remotely. The dashboard is organized in containers, where each container displays information regarding similar sensor data in an easily interpreted fashion. Gauges show the danger levels associated with a reading, and are thus used extensively. The colour warnings and indicators are designed to easily stand out to the user, thereby warning them to take action more effectively.

As the final link in starting the execution of the pod run, the pod starts when the user presses the "start" button, after which all subsequent operations are autonomous. However, the user has the option to enter "Manual Mode", where the user can then activate brakes and control the LIM operating frequency.

This is our GOOSE X pod, a conceptual full size Hyperloop vehicle inspired by the prototype we are building. The full size pod will have a capacity of 26 passengers per pod, interior diameter of 2 meters, top speed around 1220 km/h and cost around $500,000 per pod.

sections.title: Exterior Design
content: The exterior design of the pod highlights its primary design feature: the geodetic structural frame. The front end of the pod features a funnel like shape which would be used to collect the small amount of low pressure air in front of the train to eliminate air drag and supply air for the compressor which supplies the air castors. The matte black finish departs from contemporary transit imagery and signals in the new era of Hyperloop transit.

sections.title: Interior Design
content: Due to cost efficiency, the diameter of the Hyperloop track must be kept as minimal as possible. For this reason, the pod design is kept as small as possible, and the curved geometry, white colour palette, and use of interior features resembling windows creates the illusion of a much bigger space
